questions.question: When would VDF be used for a position fix?

options.content: When an aircraft declares an emergency on any frequency
When first talking to an FIR on crossing an international boundary
When joining controlled airspace from uncontrolled airspace
When declaring an emergency on 121.500 MHz

questions.question: What equipment does an aircraft need when carrying out a VDF let-down?
Which of the following is an advantage of a VDF let-down?

options.content: No equipment required in the aircraft
No special equipment required in the aircraft or on the ground
Only a VHF radio is needed in the aircraft
It is pilot interpreted, so ATC is not required

questions.question: What is the maximum range at which a VDF station at 325 ft can provide a service to an aircraft at FL080?
Which of the following statements regarding VHF direction finding (VDF) is most accurate?

options.content: It is simple and only requires a VHF radio on the ground
It is simple and requires a VHF radio and DF equipment in the aircraft
It is simple requiring only VHF radios on the ground and in the aircraft
It uses line of sight propagation

questions.question: What is the wavelength corresponding to a frequency of 375 kHz?
An NDB transmits a signal pattern which is:
The accuracy of ADF within the DOC by day is:
Given that the compass heading is 270°, the deviation is 2°W, the variation is 30°E and the relative bearing of a beacon is 316°, determine the QDR:

Two NDBs, one 20 NM from the coast and the other 50 NM further inland.

Assuming coastal error is the same for each, from which NDB will an aircraft flying over the sea receive the greatest error?

options.content: Same when the relative bering is 090/270
Same when the relative bearing is 180/360

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the greatest effect on the accuracy of ADF bearings?

options.content: Interference from other NDBs particularly by day
Interference from other NDBs, particularly at night
Frequency drift at the ground station

questions.question: Which of the following are all errors associated with ADF?

options.content: Selective availability, coastal refraction, night effect
Night effect, quadrantal error, lane slip
Mountain effect, station interference, static interference
Selective availability, coastal refraction, quadrantal error

questions.question: What action must be taken to receive a bearing from an ADF?

options.content: Both the loop and sense aerials must receive the signal

questions.question: When is coastal error at its worst for an aircraft at low level?

options.content: Beacon inland at an acute angle to the coast
Beacon inland at 90° to the coast
Beacon close to the coast at an acute angle to the coast
Beacon close to the coast at 90° to the coast

questions.question:
A radio beacon has a range of 10 NM.

By what factor should the power be increased to achieve a range of 20 NM?
Which of the following is the most significant error in ADF?
Which of the following may cause inaccuracies in ADF bearings?

options.content: Static interference, height effect, lack of failure warning
Station interference, mountain effect, selective availability
Coastal refraction, slant range, night effect
Lack of failure warning, station interference, static interference

questions.question: The allocated frequency coverage of NDBs is:
The principle used to measure VOR bearings is:
When converting VOR and ADF bearings to true, the variation at the ____ should be used for VOR and at the ____ for ADF.

An aircraft flies from a VOR at 61N 013W to 58N 013W.

The variation at the beacon is 13W and the variation at the aircraft is 5W. What radial is the aircraft on?

I n a conventional VOR the reference signal and the variable signal have a 30 Hz modulation.

The variable signal modulation is produced by:

options.content: adding 30 Hz to the transmitted signal
a 30 Hz rotation producing a 30 Hz modulation
varying the amplitude up and down at +/-30 Hz
using Doppler techniques to produce a 30 Hz amplitude modulation

questions.question: If the VOR accuracy has a limit of 1.0°, what is the maximum cross-track error at 200 NM?
What is the maximum distance apart a VOR and TACAN can be located and have the same identification?
What is the maximum distance between VOR beacons designating the centre line of an airway (10 NM wide), if the expected VOR bearing error is 5.5°?

In a certain VORTAC installation the VOR is coding STN and the DME is coding STZ.

This means that the distance between the two beacons is in excess of:

The maximum range an aircraft at FL370 can receive transmissions from a VOR/DME at 800 ft is:
When tracking a VOR radial inbound the aircraft would fly:
Which of the following is a valid frequency (MHz) for a VOR?
Using a VOR beyond the limits of the DOC may result in:

options.content: loss of signal due to line of sight limitations
interference from other VORs operating on the same frequency
sky wave contamination of the VOR signal

questions.question:
An aircraft is flying a heading of 090° along the equator, homing to a VOR.

If variation at the aircraft is 10°E and 15°E at the VOR, what is the inbound radial?
When identifying a co-located VOR/DME the following signals are heard in the Morse code every 30 seconds:

options.content: 4 identifications with the DME at a higher tone
4 identifications with the DME at a lower tone
no DME identification, but if the VOR identification is present and a range is indicated then this shows that both are serviceable

questions.question: What is the maximum range a transmission from a VOR beacon at 169 ft can be received by an aircraft at FL012?

An aircraft is tracking inbound to a VOR beacon on the 105 radial.

The setting the pilot should put on the OBS and the CDI indications are:
When tracking the 090 radial outbound from a VOR, the track flown is:
The frequency band of VOR is:
On which radial from a VOR at 61N025E (VAR 13°E) is an aircraft at 59N025E (VAR 20°E)?
What is the minimum height an aircraft must be to receive signals from a VOR at 196 ft AMSL at a range of 175 NM?
For a conventional VOR a phase difference of 090° would be achieved by flying ____ from the beacon:
At a range of 200 NM from a VOR, if there is an error of 1°, how far off the centre line is the aircraft?
The quoted accuracy of VOR is valid:

options.content: at all times except dawn and dusk

questions.question: Which of the following provides distance information?
Which of the following would give the best indication of speed?

options.content: A VOR on the flight plan route
A VOR off the flight plan route
A DME on the flight plan route
A DME off the flight plan route

questions.question: What happens when a DME in the search mode fails to achieve lock-on?

options.content: It stays in the search mode, but reduces to 60 pulse pairs per second (ppps) after 100 seconds
It stays in the search mode, but reduces to 60 ppps after 15 000 pulse pairs
It stays in the search mode at 150 ppps
It alternates between search and memory modes every 10 seconds

questions.question: The most accurate measurement of speed by DME for an aircraft at 30 000 ft will be when the aircraft is:

options.content: tracking towards the beacon at 10 NM
tracking away from the beacon at 100 NM
passing abeam the beacon at 5 NM

questions.question: A DME beacon will become saturated when more than about _____ aircraft are interrogating the transponder.
A typical DME frequency is:
The DME in an aircraft, cruising at FL210, fails to achieve lock-on a DME at MSL at a range of 210 NM. The reason for this is:

options.content: the aircraft is beyond the maximum usable range for DME
the aircraft is beyond line of sight range
the aircraft signal is too weak at that range to trigger a response

questions.question: The aircraft DME receiver accepts replies to its own transmissions but rejects replies to other aircraft transmissions because:

options.content: the PRF of the interrogations is unique to each aircraft
the pulse pairs from each aircraft have a unique amplitude modulation
the interrogation frequencies are 63 MHz different for each aircraft
the interrogation and reply frequencies are separated by 63 MHz

questions.question: When an aircraft at FL360 is directly above a DME, at mean sea level, the range displayed will be:
A DME frequency could be:
An aircraft at FL360 is 10 NM plan range from a DME. The DME reading in the aircraft will be:
A DME transceiver does not lock onto its own reflections because:

options.content: the PRF of the pulse pairs is jittered
the interrogation and reply frequencies differ
the reflections will all fall within the flyback period

questions.question: What information does military TACAN provide for civil aviation users?
The DME in an aircraft flying at FL430 shows a range of 15 NM from a beacon at an elevation of 167 ft. The plan range is:
What are the DME frequencies?

The time from the transmission of the interrogation pulse to the receipt of the reply from the DME ground station is 2000 microseconds (ignore the delay at the DME).

The slant range is:
The DME counters are rotating continuously. This indicates that:

options.content: the DME is trying to lock onto range
the DME is trying to lock onto frequency
the DME is receiving no response from the ground station

questions.question: On a DME presentation the counters are continuously rotating. This indicates:

options.content: the DME is in the search mode
the DME is receiving no response from the transponder

questions.question: An aircraft at FL200 is 220 NM from a DME at MSL. The aircraft equipment fails to lock on to the DME. This is because:

options.content: the aircraft is too high to receive the signal
the aircraft is too low to receive the signal

questions.question: On an ILS approach you receive more of the 90 Hz modulation than the 150 Hz modulation. The action you should take is:
The errors of an ILS localizer (LLZ) beam are due to:

options.content: spurious signals from objects near the runway
interference from other systems operating on the same frequency

questions.question: The amplitude modulation of the ILS outer marker is _____ and it illuminates the _____ light in the cockpit.
The principle of operation of the ILS localizer transmitter is that it transmits two overlapping lobes on:

options.content: the same frequency with different phases
the same frequency with different amplitude modulations
different frequencies with different amplitude modulations

questions.question: The ILS glide slope transmitter generates false glide paths because of:

options.content: ground returns from the vicinity of the transmitter
multiple lobes in the radiation pattern
reflections from obstacles in the vicinity of the transmitter

questions.question: A category III ILS system provides accurate guidance down to:
A HSI compass rose is stuck on 200°. When the aircraft is lined up on the centre line of the ILS localizer for runway 25, the localizer needle will be:

options.content: centred with the fail flag showing

questions.question: The coverage of the ILS glide slope with respect to the localizer centre line is:
The middle marker is usually located at a range of ____ with an audio frequency of _____ and illuminates the _____ light.
The sequence of marker colours when flying an ILS approach is:

options.content: category I ILS operations are in progress
category II/III ILS operations are in progress

questions.question: The ILS localizer is normally positioned:

options.content: 300 m from the downwind end of the runway
300 m from the upwind end of the runway

questions.question: The audio frequency of the outer marker is:
An aircraft is flying downwind outside the coverage of the ILS. The CDI indications will be:

options.content: reliable in azimuth, unreliable in elevation

questions.question: The frequency band of the ILS glide path is:
In which band does the ILS glide path operate?
The coverage of MLS is _____ either side of the centre line to a distance of _____

options.content: measuring the time taken for the primary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft receiver
measuring the time taken for the secondary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft receiver
phase comparison between the azimuth and elevation beams

questions.question: Which of the following is an advantage of MLS?

options.content: Can be used in inhospitable terrain
Uses the same aircraft equipment as ILS
Is not affected by heavy precipitation

questions.question: The frequency band of MLS is:
Primary radar operates on the principle of:
The definition of a radar display will be best with:

options.content: more complex equipment but better resolution and accuracy
permits measurement of Doppler in addition to improved range and bearing

questions.question:
Which of the following systems use pulse technique?

1. secondary surveillance radar

2. airborne weather radar

3. distance measuring equipment

4. primary radar

In a primary pulsed radar the ability to discriminate in azimuth is a factor of:
The maximum range of a ground radar is limited by:
What does pulse recurrence rate refer to?

options.content: the number of cycles per second
the number of pulses per second
the ratio of pulse width to pulse repetition period
the delay known as flyback or dead time

questions.question: The maximum PRF required for a range of 50 NM is:
The best radar for measuring very short ranges is:
Which is the most suitable radar for measuring short ranges?
The main advantage of a slotted scanner is:

options.content: reduces side lobes and directs more energy into the main beam
removes the need for azimuth slaving
can produce simultaneous map and weather information

questions.question: The maximum unambiguous (theoretical) range for a PRF of 1200 pps is:

The PRF of a radar is 450 pps.

If the speed of light is 300 000 km/s, what is the maximum range of the radar?

On what principle does primary ATC radar work?
The airborne weather radar (AWR) cannot detect:
The frequency of AWR is:
The use of the AWR on the ground is:

options.content: permitted provided reduced power is used
permitted provided special precautions are taken to safeguard personnel and equipment
only permitted to assist movement in low visibility conditions

questions.question: Which type of cloud does the AWR detect?
The AWR uses the cosecant squared beam in the ___ mode.
On the AWR display the most severe turbulence will be shown:
On an AWR colour display, the sequence of colours indicating increasing water droplet size is:
In an AWR with a 5° beamwidth, how do you orientate the scanner to receive returns from clouds at or above your level?
The ISO-ECHO circuit is incorporated in the AWR:

options.content: to alert pilots to the presence of cloud
to display areas of turbulence in cloud
to allow simultaneous mapping and cloud detection

questions.question: The main factors which affect whether an AWR will detect a cloud are:

options.content: the size of the water droplets and the diameter of the antenna reflector
the scanner rotation rate and the frequency/wavelength
the size of the water droplets and the wavelength/frequency
the size of the water droplets and the range of the cloud

questions.question: In an AWR with a colour CRT, areas of greatest turbulence are indicated by:
As a storm intensifies, the colour sequence on the AWR display will change:
The cosecant squared beam is used for mapping in the AWR because:

options.content: a greater range can be achieved
a wider beam is produced in azimuth to give a greater coverage
a larger area of ground is illuminated by the beam
it allows cloud detection to be effected whilst mapping

questions.question:
The AWR can be used on the ground provided:

1. the aircraft is clear of personnel, buildings and vehicles

2. conical beam is selected

3. maximum uptilt is selected

4. the AWR must never be operated on the ground
Doppler navigation systems use _____ to determine the aircraft ground speed and drift.

options.content: phase comparison of signals from ground stations
frequency shift in signals reflected from the ground

questions.question: Which axes is the AWR stabilized in?

options.content: SSR does not use the echo principle
By the use of MTI to remove stationary and slow moving returns

questions.question: The advantages of SSR mode S are:

The SSR ground transceiver interrogates on ____ and receives responses on ____
The vertical position provided by SSR mode C is referenced to:

options.content: QNH unless QFE is in use

questions.question: Why is a secondary radar display free from weather clutter?

options.content: The frequencies are too low to detect water droplets
The frequencies are too high to detect water droplets
Moving target indication is used to suppress the static generated by water droplets
The principle of the return of echoes is not used

questions.question: The availability of 4096 codes in SSR is applicable to mode:
With reference to SSR, what code is used to indicate transponder altitude failure?
In NAVSTAR/GPS the PRN codes are used to:

options.content: eliminate satellite clock and ephemeris errors

questions.question: The MDA for a non-precision approach using NAVSTAR/GPS is based on:
If, during a manoeuvre, a satellite being used for position fixing is shadowed by the wing, the effect on position will be:

options.content: another satellite will be selected, so there will be no degradation of position
the GPS will maintain lock using reflections of the signals from the fuselage

questions.question: The time required for a GNSS receiver to download the satellite almanac for the NAVSTAR/GPS is:
The effect of the ionosphere on NAVSTAR/GPS accuracy is:

options.content: only significant for satellites close to the horizon
minimized by the receivers using a model of the ionosphere to correct the signals

questions.question: The height derived by a receiver from the NAVSTAR/GPS is:
The NAVSTAR/GPS constellation comprises:
Selective availability may be used to degrade the accuracy of the NAVSTAR/GPS position. This is achieved by:

options.content: introducing an offset in the satellites clocks
random dithering of the broadcast satellites clock time
random dithering of the broadcast satellites X, Y & Z coordinates
introducing an offset in the broadcast satellites X, Y & Z coordinates

questions.question: The positioning of a GNSS aerial on an aircraft is:

options.content: on the fuselage as close as possible to the receiver
on top of the fuselage close to the centre of gravity

questions.question: The NAVSTAR/GPS space segment:

options.content: provides X, Y & Z coordinates and monitoring of the accuracy of the satellite data
provides X, Y, Z & T coordinates and the constellation data
monitors the accuracy of the satellite data and provides system time

questions.question: Concerning NAVSTAR/GPS orbits, which of the following statements is correct?

options.content: The inclination of the orbits is 55° with an orbital period of 12 hours
The inclination of the orbits is 55° with an orbital period of 24 hours
The orbits are geostationary to provide global coverage
The orbits are inclined at 65° with an orbital period of 11 hours 15 minutes

questions.question: NAVSTAR GPS receiver clock error is removed by:

options.content: regular auto-synchronization with the satellite clocks
adjusting the pseudo-ranges to determine the error
synchronization with the satellite clocks on initialization
having an appropriate atomic time standard within the receiver

questions.question: The contents of the navigation and systems message from NAVSTAR/GPS SVs include:

options.content: satellite clock error, almanac data, ionospheric propagation information
satellite clock error, almanac data, satellite position error
position accuracy verification, satellite clock time and clock error
ionospheric propagation information, X, Y & Z coordinates and corrections, satellite clock time and error

questions.question: The NAVSTAR/GPS segments are:
The preferred GNSS receiver for airborne application is:
The orbital height of geostationary satellites is:
The best accuracy from satellite systems will be provided by:
The azimuth and elevation of the satellites is:

options.content: determined by the satellite and transmitted to the receiver
determined by the receiver from the satellite almanac data
transmitted by the satellite as part of the almanac
determined by the receiver from the broadcast satellite X, Y, Z & T data

questions.question: The skysearch carried out by a GNSS receiver:

options.content: is done prior to each fix
is done when the receiver position is in error
involves the receiver downloading the almanac from each satellite before determining which satellites are in view
is the procedure carried out by the monitoring stations to check the accuracy of the satellite data

questions.question: An aircraft GNSS receiver is using 5 satellites for RAIM. If the receiver deselects one satellite then the flight should be continued:

options.content: using 4 satellites with the pilot monitoring the receiver output
using alternative radio navigation systems only

questions.question: The WGS84 model of the earth is:

options.content: an exact model of the earth

questions.question: The frequency band of the NAVSTAR/GPS L1 and L2 frequencies is:
The number of satellites required to produce a 4D fix is:
How many satellites are needed for a 2D fix?
Which of the following statements concerning ionospheric propagation errors is true?

options.content: They are significantly reduced by the use of RAIM
They are eliminated using differential techniques
They are significantly reduced when a second frequency is available
Transmitting the state of the ionosphere to the receivers enables the error to reduced to less than one metre

questions.question: Using differential GNSS for a non-precision approach, the height reference is:
The number of satellites required to provide a 3D fix without RAIM is:
The number of satellites required for a fully operational NAVSTAR/GPS is:
ˋUnauthorizedˊ civilian users of NAVSTAR/GPS can access:
When using GPS to fly airways, what is the vertical reference used?
The nav/system message from GLONASS and NAVSTAR/GPS is found in the _____ band.
Which GNSS system can be used for IFR flights in Europe?

During flight using NAVSTAR/GPS and conventional navigation systems, you see a large error between the positions given by the systems.

The action you should take is:

options.content: switch off the faulty system after determining which one is in error

questions.question: What information can a GPS fix using four satellites give you?

What are the basic elements transmitted by NAVSTAR/GPS satellites?

1. offset of the satellite clock from GMT

2. ephemeris data

3. health data

4. ionospheric delays

5. solar activity
What is the purpose of the GPS control segment?

options.content: To control the use of the satellites by unauthorized users
To monitor the satellites in orbit
To maintain the satellites in orbit
Degrade the accuracy of satellites for unauthorized users

questions.question: In GNSS a fix is obtained by:

options.content: measuring the time taken for signals from a minimum number of satellites to reach the aircraft
measuring the time taken for the aircraft transmissions to travel to a number of satellites in known positions and return to the aircraft
measuring the pulse lengths of the sequential signals from a number of satellites in known positions
measuring the phase angle of the signals from a number of satellites in known positions

questions.question: The inclination of a satellite is:

options.content: the angle between the SV orbit and the equator
the angle between the SV orbit and the polar plane
90° minus the angle between the SV orbit and the equator
90° minus the angle between the SV orbit and the polar plane

questions.question: How is the distance between the NAVSTAR/GPS SV and the receiver determined?

options.content: By referencing the SV and receiver positions to WGS84
By synchronizing the receiver clock with the SV clock
By measuring the time from transmission to reception and multiplying by the speed of light
By measuring the time from transmission to reception and dividing by the speed of light

questions.question: The distance measured between a satellite and a receiver is known as a pseudorange because:

options.content: it is measured using pseudo-random codes
satellite and receiver are continually moving in relation to each other
it is measured against idealized Keplerian orbits

questions.question: The task of the control segment is to:

options.content: monitor the SV ephemeris and clock

questions.question: To provide 3D fixing with RAIM and allowing for the loss of one satellite requires _____ SVs:
In NAVSTAR/GPS the PRN codes are used to:

options.content: pass satellite time and ephemeris information
pass satellite time, ephemeris and other information

questions.question: An ˋall in viewˊ satellite navigation receiver is one which:

options.content: selects and tracks all (in view) satellites and selects the best four

questions.question: Which GPS frequencies are available for commercial air transport?
Which GNSS is authorized for use on European airways?
In GPS on which frequencies are both the C/A and P codes transmitted?
The orbits of the NAVSTAR GPS satellites are inclined at:

options.content: 55° to the plane of the equator
99° to the plane of the equator

questions.question: RAIM is achieved:

options.content: by ground monitoring stations determining the satellite range errors which are relayed to receivers via geo-stationary satellites
by ground stations determining the X, Y & Z errors and passing the corrections to receivers using pseudolites

questions.question: The function of the receiver in the GNSS user segment is to:

options.content: interrogate the satellites to determine range
track the satellites to calculate time
track the satellites to calculate range
determine position and assess the accuracy of that position

questions.question: In which frequency band are the L1 and L2 frequencies of GNSS?
Which of the following statements concerning differential GPS (DGPS) is true?

options.content: Local area DGPS gives the same improvement in accuracy regardless of distance from the station
DGPS removes SV ephemeris and clock errors and propagation errors
DGPS can improve the accuracy of SA affected position information
Wide area DGPS accuracy improves the closer the aircraft is to a ground station

questions.question: The visibility of GPS satellites is:

options.content: dependent on the location of the user
the same at all points on and close to the surface of the earth

questions.question: In an RNAV approach phase with a two dot lateral deviation HSI display, a one dot deviation from track would represent:
The required accuracy of a precision RNAV (P-RNAV) system is:
The ETA generated by the FMS will be most accurate:

options.content: when the forecast W/V equals the actual W/V and the FMS calculated Mach No. equals the actual Mach No
if the ground speed and position are accurate
if the forecast W/V at take-off is entered
if the ground speed is correct and the take-off time has been entered

questions.question: When is the FMS position likely to be least accurate?
For position fixing the B737-800 FMC uses:

options.content: any combination of VOR, DME and ADF

questions.question: When using a two dot HSI, a deviation of one dot from the computed track represents approximately:

An aircraft, using a 2D RNAV computer, is 12 NM from the phantom station, 25 NM from the VOR/DME designating the phantom station and the phantom station is 35 NM from the VOR/DME.

The range read-out in the aircraft will be:
The FMC position is:

options.content: the average of the IRS positions
the average of the IRS and radio navigation positions
computer generated from the IRS and radio navigation positions
computer generated from the radio navigation positions

questions.question: When midway between two waypoints, how can the pilot best check the progress of the aircraft?

options.content: By using the ATD at the previous waypoint
By using the computed ETA for the next waypoint
By using the ATA at the previous waypoint
By using the ETA at the destination

questions.question: Which of the following can be input manually to the FMC using a maximum of 5 alphanumerics?

options.content: Waypoints, latitude and longitude, SIDs and STARs
ICAO aerodrome designators, navigation facilities, SIDs and STARs
Waypoints, airways designators, latitude and longitude
Navigation facilities, reporting points, airways designators

questions.question: The inputs to the EHSI display during automatic flight include:

options.content: IRS, FMC and radio navigation facilities

questions.question: The inputs the pilot will make to the FMC during the pre-flight initialization will include:

options.content: ETD, aircraft position, and planned route
planned route, aircraft position, and departure runway
navigation data base, aircraft position and departure aerodrome
departure runway, planned route and ETD

questions.question: In RNAV mode one dot on the EHSI represents:
The phantom station in a 2D RNAV system may be generated by:

options.content: because the computer cannot determine if the aircraft is within the DOC of the programmed facilities
because the computer cannot determine if the heading and altitude input are in error
because the pilot cannot verify the correct frequency has been selected
if the selected navigation facility is in excess of about 70 NM

questions.question: The FMS database can be:

options.content: altered by the pilots between the 28 day updates
read and altered by the pilots
altered by the pilots every 28 days

questions.question: Refer to Appendix A diagram C. What is the current drift?
In the B737-400 EFIS which component generates the visual display?
When is the IRS position updated?

options.content: At VOR beacons on route by the pilots

questions.question: Refer to Appendix A. Which diagram is the MAP mode?

options.content: right of the centre line and above the glide path
left of the centre line and below the glide path
right of the centre line and below the glide path
left of the centre line and above the glide path

questions.question: Refer to Appendix A. Diagram F represents:
The navigation database in the FMS:

options.content: may be modified by the pilot to meet routing requirements
may be modified by the operations staff to meet routing requirements
may be modified by national aviation authorities to meet national requirements

questions.question: In an EHSI the navigation information comes from:

options.content: IRS, radio navigation, TAS and drift

questions.question: On an EFIS display the pictured symbol represents:
According to ICAO (Annex 11), the definition of an RNAV system is:

options.content: one which enables the aircraft to navigate on any desired flight path within the coverage of appropriate ground based navigation aids or within the specified limits of self-contained on-board systems or a combination of the two

one which enables the aircraft to navigate on any desired flight path within the coverage of appropriate ground based navigation aids or within the specified limits of self-contained on-board systems but not a combination of the two
one which enables the aircraft to navigate on any desired flight path within the coverage of appropriate ground based navigation aids only
one which enables the aircraft to navigate on any desired flight path within the specified limits of self-contained on-board systems

questions.question: Which of the following is independent of external inputs?

options.content: that a manual track has been selected
that a manual heading has been selected
the actual aircraft track over the ground, which will coincide with the aircraft heading when there is zero drift
the aircraft actual track which will coincide with the planned track when there is zero drift

questions.question:
The EHSI is showing 5° fly right with a TO indication. The aircraft heading is 280°(M) and the required track is 270°.

The radial is:

options.content: The display blanks and a fail warning appears
A fail flag is displayed alongside the display bar

questions.question: In an RNAV system which combination of external reference will give the most accurate position?

options.content: By removal of the deviation bar and pointer
By showing a fail flag alongside the deviation bar
A flashing red FAIL message appears in the frequency location
An amber FAIL message appears in the frequency location

questions.question: The colour used on the B737-400 EHSI weather display to show turbulence is:

options.content: the VOR must be identified by the pilot
the VOR must be within range when the waypoint is input
the VOR need not be in range when input or used
the VOR need not be in range when input but must be when used

questions.question: Which EHSI modes cannot show AWR information?

Comparing the L1 and L2 signals helps with the reduction of which GNSS error?
The normal maximum range for an ATC surveillance radar is:
The cause of a RNAV giving erratic readings would be:

options.content: the aircraft is in the cone of confusion of the phantom station
the aircraft is beyond line of sight range of the phantom station
the aircraft is beyond line of sight range of the reference station
the aircraft is outside the DOC of the reference station

questions.question: Flying an ILS approach with a 3° glide slope referenced to 50 ft above the threshold, an aircraft at 4.6 NM should be at an approximate height of:
The height of the GPS constellation is:
What are the ground components of MLS?

options.content: Separate azimuth and elevation antennae with DME
Separate azimuth and elevation antennae with middle and outer markers
Combined azimuth and elevation antennae with DME
Combined azimuth and elevation antennae with middle and outer markers

questions.question: The accuracy required of a basic area navigation (B-RNAV) system is:
What function does the course line computer perform?

options.content: Uses VOR/DME information to direct the aircraft to the facility
Uses VOR/DME information to direct the aircraft along a specified track
Converts VOR/DME information into HSI directions to maintain the planned track
Uses VOR/DME information to determine track and distance to a waypoint

questions.question: The emissions from a non-directional beacon (NDB) are:

options.content: a cardioid with a 30 Hz rotation rate

questions.question: How does night effect affect ADF?

options.content: Causes false bearings as the goniometer locks onto the sky wave
Sky wave interference which affects the null and is worst at dawn and dusk
Interference from other NDBs which is worst at dusk and when due east of the station
Phase shift in the received signal giving random bearing errors

questions.question: What is an ADC input to the FMC?
A typical frequency for DME would be:
When flying under IFR using GPS and a multi-sensor system:

options.content: if there is a discrepancy between the GPS and multi-sensor positions, then the multi-sensor position must be regarded as suspect
the GPS must be operating and its information displayed
the multi-sensor system must be operating and its information displayed
both systems must be operating but only the primary system information needs to be displayed

questions.question: The indications from a basic RNAV are behaving erratically. The reason is likely to be:

options.content: the aircraft is in the cone of confusion of the phantom station
the aircraft is outside the DOC of the reference VOR/DME
the aircraft is below line of sight range of the reference VOR/DME
the aircraft is in the cone of confusion of the reference VOR

questions.question: What is the maximum PRF that allows detection of targets to a range of 50 km? (ignore any flyback time).
In NAVSTAR/GPS the space segment:

options.content: provides the positional information to the receiver
the receiver interrogates the satellite and the satellite provides positional information
sends information for receiver to determine latitude, longitude and time
relays positional data from the control segment

questions.question: The almanac in the receiver:

options.content: assigns the PRN codes to the satellites
is used to determine receiver clock error
is used to determine which satellites are above the horizon

questions.question: In a RNAV system the DME is tuned:

options.content: by what is selected on the pilots DME and hence is tuned manually
automatically by taking pilotˊs DME selection
by selecting DMEs to give suitable angle of cut to get a fix automatically
by automatically selecting the nearest suitable DME

questions.question: Which input to the FMC is taken from sources external to the aircraft?

options.content: Magnetic heading from a direct reading compass

questions.question: In NAVSTAR/GPS range measurement is achieved by measuring:

options.content: the time difference between the minimum number of satellites
the time taken for the signal to travel from the satellite to the receiver
the synchronization of the satellite and receiver clocks
the time taken for a signal to travel from the receiver to the satellite and return to the receiver

questions.question: Quadrantal error in the ADF is caused by:

options.content: the metallic structure of the aircraft
generative voltages caused by the rotation of the engines
the electrical wiring running through the aircraft

questions.question: For the FMC the take-off speeds, V1, VR and V2 are found:

options.content: in the operating manual and input to the FMC
in the checklist and input manually

questions.question: The optimum climb and descent speeds used by the FMC are found:

options.content: in the operating manual and input to the FMC
in the checklist and input manually

questions.question: The optimum cruise speeds used by the FMC are found:

options.content: in the operating manual and input to the FMC
in the checklist and input manually

questions.question: Which of the following external inputs is required by the FMC to determine W/V?
Which of the following is true concerning the use of GNSS position in the FMC?

options.content: It is used to verify and update the IRS position
An alternate source of position must be used and displayed
GNSS position is usable stand alone
GNSS data may only be used in the absence of other positional information
